Impermanence Chapter, Chapter 1, 21 Verses. The Impermanence Chapter is about awakening from confusion and disorder, the difficulty of preserving glory and life, and that only the Way is true.
When waking from sleep, one should joyfully contemplate and listen to what I say,
recording the Buddha's words.
What is practiced is impermanent, referring to the Dharma of rise and fall. All that is born will die; this cessation is bliss.
It is like a potter making vessels out of clay; all will eventually break;
human life is also like this.
Like a swiftly flowing river, going without returning;
human life is like this, those who depart do not return.
It is like a person holding a staff, herding and feeding cattle;
old age and death are also like this, nourishing life and passing on.
Thousands and hundreds, not just one, of clansmen, men and women, accumulate wealth, all of which will decline and be lost.
Those who are born, day and night, their lives are being cut short, the end of their lives
is like a stream of water.
What is constant will all end, what is high will also fall, what comes together will separate, those who are born will die.
Sentient beings harm each other, losing their lives, falling into their next life according to their actions, experiencing their own retribution of misfortune and blessings.
The old see suffering and pain, at death the mind departs;
enjoying the family, bound in prison, greedily clinging to the world without ceasing.
Alas, old age arrives, the complexion changes, becoming senile;
youthful desires are not fulfilled, old age is seen as trampled upon.
Although living a hundred years, one still dies and passes away;
hated by old age, the net of illness arrives.
This day has already passed, life then follows in decreasing, like a fish with little water,
What pleasure is there in this?
When old, one's appearance fades, one's illnesses naturally destroy oneself, one's form decays and rots, and one's life ends naturally.
What use is this body?
Constantly leaking and foul, afflicted by illness, with the troubles of old age and death.
Delighting in self-indulgence, non-dharma increases, one does not see or hear changes,
and life is impermanent.
One cannot rely on having children, nor on one's father or siblings, when pressed by death, there is no relative to rely on.
Day and night, lazy and arrogant, old age does not stop desire, having wealth one does not give, not accepting the Buddha's words.
Having these four faults, one deceives oneself.
Not in the sky, not in the ocean, not entering the mountains or rocks,
There is no place where one can escape death.
This is my work, I should do it, I should make it so,
People are disturbed by this, and tread through old age, death, and worry.
Knowing this, one can purify oneself, and thus see the end of birth,
The bhiká¹£u who tires of MÄra's troops, will be liberated from birth and death.

The Chapter on Learning, the Chapter on Learning, the SÅ«tra of the Dharma Verses, Chapter 20, with 29 sections. The Chapter on Learning is about guiding one's practice, dispelling one's own ignorance, and attaining the illumination of the path.
Alas!
Why sleep?
Like a worm, snail, or oyster, hidden and covered with impurity, deludedly taking it as a body.
How can one be cut and wounded, with a mind like a suffering infant,
Encountering various calamities and difficulties, yet still sleep?
Contemplate and do not be negligent, be kind and learn the traces of kindness,
From this there will be no worries, always contemplate extinguishing one's own mind.
Right view increases with learning, this is the illumination of the world,
The merit they generate is a thousand times greater, and they will never fall into evil realms.
Do not study minor paths, have faith in wrong views, do not indulge in licentiousness,
Causing desire to increase;

Cultivate the practice of the Dharma well, study and recite without transgression, practice the path without worry, and be constantly at ease throughout all lifetimes.ğŸ”½Compassionately study and restrain the body, always be cautious in thoughts and speech,
This leads to immortality, practicing cessation to attain peace.ğŸ”½Do not study what is not to be done, but should practice what is to be done,
Having known what is to be contemplated,
Then the defilements can be extinguished.ğŸ”½Seeing the benefits of the Dharma for the body, the husband reaches the good method, knowing the benefits and practicing diligently,
This is called wise and bright.ğŸ”½As for the meaning of arousing understanding, study cessation to be firm,
Attachment to cessation and self-indulgence, diminishing without arising.ğŸ”½This is heading towards strength, this is attaining the middle through study,
From this, understanding the meaning,
It is appropriate to remember and practice.
First, cut off the mother, then the ruler and two ministers, abandon all entanglements, and you are a true monk.
Learning has no companions, and one cannot find good friends. It is better to guard goodness alone, not to associate with the foolish.
Enjoy the precepts and practice learning, what use are companions?
Alone, with goodness, without worry, like a wild elephant.
Precepts and hearing are both good, which is more virtuous?
Only when precepts and hearing are equal should one study and practice diligently.
First, protect the precepts, open and close firmly, give without receiving, practice diligently without lying down.
If a person lives a hundred years, practicing wrong learning with an unwholesome mind,
it is not as good as being born for a day, diligently accepting the true Dharma.
If a person lives a hundred years, serving fire and practicing strange arts,
it is not as good as a brief moment, serving the precepts, with blessings praised.
If one can practice and speak of it, that is acceptable; if one cannot, do not speak empty words.
Deceitful and without sincerity, one will be abandoned by the wise.
One should first seek understanding in learning, observe and distinguish right from wrong,
Accept the truth and teach others, with wisdom one will no longer be deluded.
Shaving the head and learning wrong paths, wearing grass robes while internally greedy and defiled,
Dull and ignorant of the truth, like the deaf listening to the five tones.
Learning can abandon the three evils, using medicine to dispel all poisons,
The strong man crosses birth and death, like a snake shedding its old skin.
Learning and being well-versed, upholding precepts without transgression, praised in two lifetimes,
One attains what one wishes for;
Learning and being unlearned, upholding precepts incompletely, suffering in two lifetimes, losing one's original vow.
There are two kinds of learning:
Always befriending the learned, peacefully understanding the meaning, even in hardship one does not go astray.
Weeds harm rice, and excessive desires hinder learning. Remove all evils,
And the harvest will surely be abundant.
Thinking before speaking, words are not forceful. Explaining the Dharma and its meaning, speaking without contradiction,
Skillfully learning without transgression, fearing the Dharma and understanding taboos, Seeing the subtle and knowing, warning against future troubles.
Far from sin and merit, striving to accomplish pure conduct, Controlling oneself throughout life,
This is called skillful learning.

Chapter on Extensive Learning, Fascicle 30, with 19 chapters. The chapter on extensive learning also encourages learning through hearing. Accumulating learning leads to sagehood and self-realization of perfect enlightenment.
Extensive learning can uphold firmly, and upholding the Dharma is like a wall.
Diligence is difficult to surpass or violate, and from this precepts and wisdom are accomplished;
Extensive learning illuminates the will, and once illuminated, wisdom increases.
Wisdom then comprehends widely and understands the meaning. Seeing the meaning and practicing the Dharma peacefully;
Much learning can remove worries and bring about joy through concentration,
Well-expounding the sweet dew Dharma, one can attain nirvana for oneself.
Learning enables one to know the Dharma and Vinaya, resolve doubts and see the truth,
From learning, one abandons non-Dharma and practices to reach the deathless state.
The teacher can manifest the Way, resolve doubts and make students understand clearly,
And also establish the pure basis, able to uphold the Dharma treasury.
Able to grasp the meaning, understanding then the meaning is not flawed,
Those who receive the Dharma and rely on the Dharma, from this quickly attain peace.
If one has much or little learning, yet is arrogant and conceited,
This is like a blind person holding a candle, illuminating others but not oneself.
If one seeks official rank, wealth, nobility, and heavenly blessings,
Eloquence and wisdom in the world, learning is the foremost.
Kings and nobles honor learning, the heavens and gods are also so,
Hearing is the foremost treasure, the richest, and the strongest.
The wise bend for the sake of hearing, and those who love the Way also delight in it.
The king serves with all his heart, and so do the Shakra and Brahma gods.
The sages always respect hearing, let alone the noble and wealthy.
Therefore, wisdom is noble, and there is no greater one to be revered than this.
One serves the sun for its brightness, and one serves one's father out of gratitude.
One serves the ruler for his power, and one serves the Way for the sake of hearing.
One serves a doctor for one's life, and one relies on the powerful for victory.
The Dharma resides in wisdom, and blessings shine throughout the world.
One examines friends in times of consultation, and one distinguishes companions in times of urgency;
One observes wives in the pleasure of the bedroom, and one wishes to know wisdom in speech.
Hearing brings benefits in this world, to one's wife, children, siblings, and friends,
And it also brings blessings in future lives, as accumulated hearing forms sage-like wisdom.
It can scatter worries and anger, and also remove inauspicious decline.
If you wish to attain peace and good fortune, you should serve the learned.
There is no wound worse than worry, no arrow worse than foolishness.
This is a strong [arrow] that cannot be pulled out, only the learned can remove it.
The blind gain eyes from it, the dark gain light from it.
It also guides the people of the world, like eyes leading the blind.
Therefore, one should abandon foolishness, leave behind arrogance, and enjoy wealth.
Strive to learn and serve the learned, this is called accumulating virtue.

Chapter on Faithfulness, Chapter on Faithfulness, Dharma Phrases Sutra, Chapter 40 with 18 Chapters, Chapter on Faithfulness, the root of establishing the Way, the fruit of the correct view of causes, and not looking back in practice.
Faith, shame, precepts, intention, and wealth, these are praised by the refined,
This Way is spoken by the wise, thus one ascends to the heavenly world.
Fools do not cultivate heavenly conduct, nor do they praise giving.
Those who have faith and give to help the virtuous, from here they reach the other shore of peace.
Those with faith are true people of long life, contemplating the Dharma, abiding in peace;
Those who are close attain the supreme mind, wisdom and longevity, wise among the wise.
Faith can attain the Way, the Dharma leads to nirvana, from hearing one attains wisdom,
where one goes there is illumination;
Faith can cross the abyss, gathering as a guide, diligence removes suffering, wisdom reaches the other shore.
Those with faith and practice are praised by the sages, those who enjoy non-action, all bonds are untied.
Faith and precepts, the wise mind is able to practice, the strong man crosses over anger,
from this one escapes the abyss.
Faith makes precepts sincere, and also receives wisdom, wherever one is able to practice, everywhere one sees nourishment.
This wealth is the supreme treasure, family wealth is impermanent.
If you wish to see the truth, enjoy listening to the Dharma, and can abandon the defilements of stinginess,
This is called faith.
Faith can cross the river, its blessings are difficult to steal, it can stop theft, the wild Å›ramaá¹‡a delights.ğŸ”½Without faith, one does not practice, likes to peel away correct speech,
Like unskilled water-drawing, digging a spring stirs up mud.ğŸ”½The wise practice wisdom, enjoy looking up to clear streams,
Like skillfully drawing water,
Think to prevent disturbance.
Faith is not tainted by others, only the wise can associate with people, what is good can be learned, what is not good can be avoided.ğŸ”½Faith is my carriage, no one knows what it carries,
Like a well-tamed great elephant, self-taming is supreme.
Faith is wealth, precepts are wealth, shame and conscience are also wealth, learning is wealth, giving is wealth,
Faith, wealth, and precepts are wealth, as are shame and conscience. Learning, giving, and wisdom are the seven kinds of wealth.
Following faith and guarding the precepts, always contemplating the Dharma with wisdom and benefiting others, respectfully upholding and not forgetting.
Those who are born with this wealth, whether male or female, will never be poor. The wise recognize the truth.
Chapter on Caution, Chapter 50 with 16 sections of the Dharmapada. The chapter on caution is to bestow the good path and restrain evil, so that there will be no regrets later.
People who are always pure, uphold the precepts to the end, and cultivate good conduct purely,
in this way the precepts are accomplished.
The wise protect the precepts, and their blessings lead to the Three Jewels. Gaining fame and benefits, they later enjoy heavenly bliss.
Always seeing the place of the Dharma, protecting the precepts is the illumination, attaining true insight, and auspiciousness among the virtuous.
Those who uphold precepts are at ease, causing the body to be free from distress, sleeping peacefully at night,
and always joyful upon waking.
Cultivating precepts and giving, creating merit for the sake of merit, from this they go to the next, always reaching a place of peace.
What is ultimately good?
What is good and peaceful to abide in?
What is a person's treasure?
What is not taken by theft?
Precepts ultimately bring peace in old age, precepts and goodness are peaceful to abide in, wisdom is a person's treasure,
and merit is not taken by theft.
A bhiká¹£u establishes precepts, guards the sense faculties, knows moderation in food, and awakens the mind to accord with reality.
By precepts he subdues the mind, guards the mind and abides in right concentration, internally studies right contemplation, and does not forget right wisdom.
The wise and clear one guards precepts, internally contemplates right wisdom, practices the path as appropriate,
and himself removes suffering.
Eliminate all defilements, abandon arrogance, and do not give rise to it. Seek the Dharma throughout your life, and never be apart from the sages.
Precepts, concentration, wisdom, and liberation - these you should contemplate well. Having completely abandoned defilements, there are no calamities, only blessings.
If you are attached to liberation, you will cross over and not be reborn again. Transcending the realm of MÄra,
you will be like the clear sun.
If you are deluded and indulge yourself, you will always be outside. With the practice of precepts, concentration, and wisdom, seek fulfillment and do not be apart from it.
Uphold the precepts purely, and do not indulge your mind. With right wisdom and understanding, do not see heretical teachings.
This leads to auspicious places, for the unsurpassed Way. Also abandon the non-Way,
and leave the realm of MÄra.

The bhiká¹£u who understands the meaning and practices, should make it accord with this thought.
Abandoning all thoughts of birth and death, one can put an end to suffering,
Always listen to the subtle, and awaken one's own mind.
One who can awaken is wise, not meeting with beginning or end,
With awakened mind, one can accord with it, diligently studying and practicing day and night,
One will understand the essential of immortality, and cause all defilements to be extinguished.
When a person obtains good benefits, they will naturally take refuge in the Buddha,
Therefore, day and night, always think of the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha.
Knowing and awakening one's own mind, this is a disciple of the Buddha,
Always day and night, think of the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha.
Think of the body, think of impermanence, think of the virtue of precepts and giving,
Emptiness, non-aspiration, and signlessness, day and night, think of these.

Chapter 7: Benevolence and Kindness, Chapter 7 of the Dharma Phrases Sutra, with 18 sections. The chapter on benevolence and kindness is said to be what great and holy people practice, with virtue that is vast and immeasurable.
Being benevolent and not killing, always able to restrain the body, this is where there is no death,
and wherever one goes there are no worries;
Not killing and being benevolent, being careful with words and guarding the mind, this is where there is no death, and wherever one goes there are no worries.
Having already straightened what was disordered, guarding with benevolence and kindness, seeing anger and being able to endure it, this is called the practice of Brahma;
Being sincere and relaxed, with no harsh words from the mouth, not being angry with others,
this is called the practice of Brahma;
Hanging the arms down and doing nothing, not harming sentient beings, not causing any trouble, this accords with the practice of Brahma.
Always with compassion and pity, pure like the Buddha's teachings, knowing contentment and knowing moderation, this is the transcendence of birth and death.
Having few desires and delighting in learning, not confused by profit, benevolent without transgression,
Praised by the world.
Benevolent longevity without transgression, not giving rise to change or joy, people argue and disturb, wisdom is silent and at ease.
Universally concerned for virtuous friends, compassion extends to all beings, always practicing loving-kindness, wherever one goes is peaceful.
Benevolent and righteous, not deviant, peacefully abiding without worry, the heavens protect it;
The wise delight in loving-kindness, day and night contemplating loving-kindness, the mind without criticism,
Not harming any being.
This practice has no enmity; without loving-kindness, there is killing. Violating precepts, speaking falsely, faults not given to others.
Not observing sentient beings, alcohol leads to loss of resolve, engaging in unrestrained conduct, later falling into evil paths.
Without sincerity, not true, practicing benevolence and loving-kindness, extensively loving and saving the multitude,
There are eleven praises:
One will not have nightmares, be protected by the gods, be loved by people, be free from poison and weapons,
Not lose to water or fire, be successful in one's endeavors, and upon death ascend to the Brahma Heaven.
These are the eleven benefits.
If one contemplates the boundless mind of loving-kindness without neglect, one's cycle of birth and death will gradually diminish, and one will attain the benefits of transcending the world.
You should have an undisturbed mind, and loving-kindness is the most important practice. Have compassion for sentient beings, and this merit is immeasurable.
Even if one serves all the people in the world with utmost effort for the entirety of one's life,
Offering elephants, horses, and making sacrifices to the gods, it is not as good as practicing a single act of loving-kindness.
Chapter on Speech, Chapter 80 with 12 sections. The chapter on speech is about restraining the mouth, and when speaking or discussing, one should use reason.
Evil words and scolding, arrogance and contempt for others, if one engages in such actions,
Enmity and resentment will grow.

Humility means to speak in a way that accords with others, to respect people, to abandon resentment and endure evil, and to quickly extinguish enmity on one's own.ğŸ”½As for a person's birth, an axe is in the mouth,
and the reason for cutting one's own body is due to evil speech.
Disputing for a little profit is like concealing lost wealth. Following that, it leads to disputes,
causing the mind to turn towards evil.
Praising evil and what is praised by evil, these two are both evil.
Fond of using the mouth to incite fights, later on, all will be without peace.
Lacking the Way, one falls into evil paths, increasing the suffering of hell on one's own.
Far from foolishness, cultivate a mind of patience, and if one contemplates the truth, there will be no transgression.
Following goodness, one attains liberation; doing evil, one does not attain liberation.
One who skillfully understands is wise, and this is liberation from evil afflictions.
Understanding, restraining, and reducing the mind, not being agitated, and speaking appropriately,
speaking meaningfully and in accordance with the Dharma, this speech is gentle and sweet.
Therefore, in speech, one must not bring harm to oneself,
Nor be harsh to others - this is called speaking well.
Speech that pleases the mind and brings joy,
Without leading to evil thoughts, is acceptable to all.
Speaking with sincerity and nectar-like words, in accordance with the Dharma and without fault,
Truthful and in accord with the meaning and Dharma, is the establishment of the path.
Speaking as the Buddha has said leads to auspicious liberation,
And is able to bring about the boundless - this is called the supreme speech.

Chapter on the Two Essentials, Chapter 9 of the Dharma Verses Sutra, with 22 sections. The chapter on the two essentials illuminates the pairs, with good and evil corresponding, and the meaning is not single.
The mind is the root of phenomena, the mind is the master and the mind is the servant. If the mind thinks evil,
Then speaks and acts on it, suffering and evil will follow, like a cart wheel leaving tracks.
The mind is the root of phenomena, the mind is the master, the mind is the servant. If the mind thinks good,
Then speech and action will follow, and blessings and joy will naturally pursue, like a shadow following a form.
Following a confused mind, bound by delusion, entering darkness, arrogant and lacking the Dharma,
How can one understand good words?
Following a correct mind, opening up and understanding clearly, not being jealous, and skillfully understanding good words.
Being angry at an enemy never eliminates the enemy;
Not being angry naturally removes it. This is the way to be revered.
Not liking to blame others, striving to examine oneself. If one knows this,
One will forever eliminate troubles.
Not controlling food and drink, being arrogant, falling into cowardice, being controlled by evil,
Like grass swaying in the wind;
Controlling food and drink, always enjoying diligence, not being moved by evil,
Like a great mountain in the wind.
Not spitting out poisonous attitudes, with lustful thoughts running wild, unable to tame oneself, one should not wear the Dharma robes;
Able to spit out poisonous attitudes, with precepts and intentions peaceful and still, having subdued the mind and tamed it, this one should wear the Dharma robes.
Taking the genuine as false, taking the false as genuine, this is a deviant calculation,
Not attaining true benefits;
Knowing the genuine as genuine, seeing the false and knowing it is false, this is a correct calculation, certainly attaining true benefits.
If a roof is not tightly sealed, then rain will leak in; if the mind does not contemplate practice, lust and debauchery will create holes;
If a roof is well sealed, then rain will not leak in; if one focuses the mind on practice,
Lust and debauchery will not arise.
A vulgar person's defilement of others is like being near a foul-smelling object; gradually becoming confused and habituated to non-virtue, one does not realize it has become evil;
The wise are stained by people, like being near incense. Advancing wisdom practices goodness, and conduct becomes pure and fragrant.
Creating sorrow after sorrow, practicing evil brings two sorrows, they only fear sorrow,
seeing faults makes the mind anxious;ğŸ”½Creating joy after joy, practicing goodness brings two joys, they only rejoice in joy,
seeing blessings makes the mind at ease;ğŸ”½Now regretting after regret, doing evil brings two regrets, it becomes self-disaster,
receiving punishment and distress;
Now rejoicing after rejoicing, doing good brings two joys, it becomes self-blessing,
receiving blessings and delight.
Embracing lust, anger, and delusion, not contemplating cessation and insight, gathering like a herd of cattle,
are not disciples of the Buddha;
Eliminating lust, anger, and delusion, awakening to the correct intention and understanding, seeing arising and non-arising,
are disciples of the Buddha.

Chapter 10: Carelessness, Chapter on Carelessness, Dharma Phrases Sutra, Chapter 10 has 20 sections. The chapter on carelessness draws on the precepts of the Vinaya, preventing evil thoughts and guarding against mistakes, encouraging goodness with the Way.
Precepts are the path to immortality, carelessness is the path to death.
Not being greedy is not dying, losing the Way is self-destruction;
Wisdom and knowledge guard the Way, never being careless,
Not being greedy leads to joy, from this one attains the bliss of the Way.
Always contemplate the Way, be strong and guard right conduct,
The strong one attains liberation from the world, auspiciousness is unsurpassed.
Right mindfulness always arises, pure conduct easily extinguishes evil,
Restraining oneself with the Dharma, not violating increases good reputation.
Practicing without carelessness, restraining oneself to regulate the mind,
Wisdom can make concentration clear, not returning to the dark abyss.
The minds of fools are difficult to understand, they are greedy, confused, and fond of quarreling.
The wise always take this seriously, guarding it as a precious treasure.
Do not be greedy, do not quarrel, and do not indulge in desires,
If the mind is not negligent, one can attain great peace.
Negligence is like self-restraint, those who can overcome it are wise,
Having ascended the tower of wisdom, leaving danger is the same as peace.
The wise observe fools, as if comparing a mountain to the earth,
Dwelling in chaos while the body is upright, they are the only ones who awaken,
This power surpasses that of a lion, abandoning evil is great wisdom.
Sleep is heavy like a mountain, covered by the darkness of delusion,
Peacefully lying down without considering suffering, thus one always receives a womb.
Do not indulge at the wrong time, being able to restrain the defilements one can end them,
If one indulges, Mara finds an opportunity, like a lion seizing a deer.
Those who are able to control themselves are bhiká¹£us who uphold the precepts.
Those who contemplate the true and pure should always protect their minds.
Bhiká¹£us who are careful and diligent are happy, while those who are negligent have much to worry about.
Conflicts arise from small disputes and escalate to large ones, accumulating evil and entering the flames.
Upholding the precepts leads to blessings and goodness, while violating the precepts brings fear.
Those who can sever the defilements of the three realms are close to nirvÄá¹‡a.
If one is negligent before but later able to restrain oneself, this illuminates the world,
and one should contemplate and be mindful of what is appropriate.ğŸ”½If one makes mistakes and does evil but later covers them with good, this illuminates the world,
and one should contemplate and be mindful of what is good.ğŸ”½If one abandons the household life in youth and adulthood and diligently practices the Buddha's teachings,
this illuminates the world, like the moon emerging from clouds.ğŸ”½If one does evil before but later stops and does not commit offenses,
this illuminates the world,
like the moon emerging from clouds.
Born without causing harm, and not grieving at death, this is seeing the path as courageous, do not worry in the midst of it.
Learning is only pure and white, crossing the abyss without turning back, abandoning reliance and practicing cessation,
not being tainted by pleasure again, wishing to cut off worries.
Chapter on the Mind, Chapter 11 of the Dharma Verses Sutra, with 12 sections. The chapter on the mind discusses how the mind and spirit, although empty and formless, create inexhaustible karma.
The mind controls actions, which are difficult to protect and restrain. Wisdom corrects its roots,
and its illumination becomes great.
Light and restless, difficult to hold, only following desires, controlling the mind is good, self-discipline brings peace.
The mind is subtle and difficult to see, following desires in action. Wisdom always protects itself, and being able to guard it brings peace.
Walking alone, going far, covering and hiding without form, harming the mind and approaching the Way,
the bonds of Mara are then unraveled.
The mind has no resting place, and does not understand the Dharma, confused by worldly affairs, without right wisdom.
Thoughts have no fixed point, endless and boundless, blessings can stop evil, the enlightened one becomes wise.
The Buddha speaks of the mind's dharmas, although subtle, they are not true, one should be aware of the wandering mind,
do not follow the unrestrained mind.
Seeing the Dharma is most peaceful, one's wishes are fulfilled, wisdom protects subtle thoughts, cutting off the causes of suffering.
The body does not last long, all will return to the earth, the form decays and the spirit departs, dwelling temporarily, what is there to crave?
The mind preempts the place of creation, coming and going without basis, thoughts are mostly deviant and biased,
creating evil for oneself.
This is created by the mind itself, not by parents, one can strive towards the correct, to create blessings, do not turn back.
The six sense bases are like a tortoise, guarding the mind like a city, wisdom battles with Mara, victory brings no trouble.

Chapter on Flower Fragrance, Chapter 10 of the Dharma Verses Sutra, with 27 sections. The chapter on flower fragrance clarifies that learning should be practiced, using flowers to see reality, causing falsehood to return to truth.
Who can choose the ground, abandon the mirror and take the sky?
Who speaks the Dharma verses like choosing good flowers?
Learners choose the ground, abandon the mirror and take the sky;
Skillfully speaking the Dharma verses, able to pick the flowers of virtue.
Knowing the world is like a metaphor, illusory dharmas suddenly exist, cutting off the blooming flowers of Mara, not seeing birth and death;
Seeing the body is like foam, illusory dharmas are natural, cutting off the blooming flowers of Mara,
Not seeing birth and death.
The body is withered when sick, like a fallen flower;
The arrival of death is like a rushing torrent.
Greed is insatiable, dissipating people's thoughts, wealth obtained through crooked means is to deceive oneself.
Like bees gathering flowers, not disturbing color or fragrance, but taking the taste and leaving, a benevolent person enters a village like this.
Not concerned with others' actions or non-actions, always examining oneself, knowing what is right and wrong.
Like a pleasing flower with beautiful color but no fragrance, skillful speech is like this, without practice there is no attainment;
like a pleasing flower with beautiful color and fragrance, skillful speech with practice,
will surely attain its blessings.
Creating many precious flowers, forming a beautiful canopy, for those who widely accumulate virtue, their rebirth becomes even better.
Unusual herbs and fragrant flowers do not emit fragrance against the wind, but when near the path they bloom, the virtuous person's fragrance pervades.
Although sandalwood has much fragrance and blue lotus fragrant flowers are said to be true,
It is not as good as the fragrance of precepts.
The fragrance of flowers is subtle and cannot be called true. The fragrance of upholding precepts surpasses that of the heavens.
If one perfects the precepts and practices without negligence, one will attain liberation and permanently escape the path of demons.
It is like creating a canal near a great road, and lotus flowers grow in the middle,
with a fragrant and refreshing fragrance.
Although there is birth and death, ordinary beings dwell on the periphery. The wise enjoy leaving home and becoming the Buddha's disciples.
Chapter on Ignorance, Chapter 13 of the Dharmapada, with 21 sections. The chapter on ignorance is to open up the obscurity and present its tendencies, wanting to reveal the light.
A sleepless night is long, a weary road is long, and for the ignorant, birth and death are long,
without knowing the true Dharma.
The deluded mind is always dark, passing like a flowing stream, dwelling in a single practice, alone without a companion.
The foolish are attached to counting, worrying for a long time, living with the foolish is suffering, to me they are like enemies.
Having children, having wealth, the foolish only worry, I am already not myself,
why worry about children and wealth?
In summer I should stay here, in winter I should stay here, the foolish have many concerns, not knowing the changes to come.
The foolish are extremely deluded, considering themselves wise, the foolish are superior to the wise, this is called extreme foolishness.
The dull and ignorant approach the wise, like a ladle measuring flavors, although they associate for a long time,
they still do not know the Dharma;ğŸ”½The enlightened approach the wise, like the tongue tasting flavors, although associating for a short while,

they immediately understand the essentials of the Way.ğŸ”½The foolish carry out [actions] that bring suffering to themselves, delighting in the mind they do evil, bringing upon themselves grave misfortune.
Acting unwholesomely, later seeing regret and stinginess, causing tears to flow down the face,
Retribution is due to past habits;
If one's actions are virtuous, one will see joy and welcome blessings. Joyful laughter is the result of habitual delight.
If one's transgressions are not yet ripe, the fool may feel at ease, but when they ripen, one will suffer great consequences.
Where the fool hopes to be, he does not consider it to be suffering. When facing disaster and misfortune,
Only then does he know it is not good.
The fool commits evil, unable to free himself. Calamities pursue and burn him, and his crimes become blazing.
The fool likes fine food, increasing month by month. In sixteen parts, he has not thought of the Dharma even once.
The fool gives rise to thoughts, but in the end there is no benefit. He invites knives and sticks for himself,
And his retribution will be stamped.
Observing his situation, one knows he is a fool. He does not give but seeks widely,
Falling into a place without the wisdom of the Way, often engaging in evil deeds.
Those who are far from the path and close to desires are called students for the sake of food,
Because of greed and attachment to the home, they take much and offer to different surnames.
Students should not fall into the two hopes, do not be householders who are shamans,
Greed for the home goes against the holy teachings, and will lead to lack in the future.
This practice is the same as fools, it only increases desire and arrogance,
The wishes of those seeking profit are different, the intentions of those seeking the path are also different.
Therefore, those with knowledge leave to become the Buddha's disciples,
Abandoning love and letting go of worldly habits, they will never fall into birth and death.

Chapter on the Wise and Virtuous, Chapter 14 of the Dharmapada, 17 sections. The chapter on the wise and virtuous praises the wise practitioners, cultivating blessings and progressing on the path, taking the Dharma as a bright mirror.
Deeply contemplating good and evil, knowing in the mind to fear and avoid, fearing and not violating,
Will ultimately be auspicious and without worry.
Therefore, in the world, those with blessings contemplate and carry out their thoughts, and their wishes are well accomplished, with blessings and rank increasing further.
Faith in goodness and making merit, accumulating practices without weariness, believing in the hidden virtues, which will surely manifest over time.
Always avoiding unrighteousness, not associating with foolish people, thinking to follow wise friends,
and relying on the superior ones.
Joyful in the Dharma, sleeping peacefully, the mind delighted and thoughts clear, the sage expounds the Dharma, and wisdom always delights in practice.
Benevolent people and the wise, fasting and observing the precepts, upholding the Way, like the moon among the stars, illuminating the world.
The bow maker tunes the bow, the boatman tunes the boat, the carpenter tunes the wood,
the wise one tunes the body.
Just as a thick rock cannot be moved by the wind, the wise one's mind is weighty, not swayed by praise or blame;
A wise person hears the Way, their mind pure and joyful.
The essence of a great person is free from desire, wherever they are, it shines brightly.
Although they may encounter suffering or joy, they do not elevate themselves to show their wisdom.
The greatly virtuous have no worldly affairs, they do not wish for sons, wealth, or a country.
Always guarding the path of precepts and wisdom, they do not crave for wrongful wealth and nobility.
The wise know that movement is like a tree in the sand,
If one's resolve is not strong, they will follow their desires and be stained by them.
The world is all submerged in the abyss, few reach the other shore,
If there are people who wish to cross, they must strive.
If one truly desires the Way, they will study and accept the correct teachings, this is close to the other shore, liberation from death is supreme.
Cutting off the five aggregates, contemplating wisdom in stillness, not returning to the abyss, abandoning reliance and embracing its brightness.
Restraining desires, cutting off pleasure and non-action, able to save oneself,
Causing the mind to become wisdom.
Single-mindedly accepting the truth, not arising is bliss, exhausting defilements and eliminating habits,
This is attaining liberation from the world.

Arhat Chapter Arhat Chapter, Sutra of the Collection of the Wise and the Foolish, Chapter 15, with 10 sections. The Arhat Chapter speaks of the true person whose nature is free from desires, unattached, and whose mind does not change.
Departing from worries and afflictions, liberated from everything, the bonds and knots already untied,
Cold without warmth.
The mind is pure and mindful, without craving or pleasure, already crossing the abyss of delusion, like a goose abandoning a pond.
Eating in moderation, without hoarding, the mind empty and without thought, crossing the ground of various practices.
Like a bird in the sky, going far without obstruction, worldly habits exhausted,
No longer looking up for food.
With an empty mind, free from troubles, having reached the place of liberation, like a flying bird, briefly descending, then swiftly departing.
Controlling the faculties, abiding in stillness, like a well-trained horse, abandoning the habits of arrogance and conceit, respected by the gods.
Not getting angry like the earth, unmoving like a mountain, the true person is without defilements,
Cutting off the cycle of birth and death.
The mind has already rested, speech and action have also ceased, following true liberation, peacefully returning to cessation.
Abandoning desires, without attachment, breaking through the three realms of existence, hopes and intentions already cut off, this is called a superior person.
Whether in a village or wilderness, on level ground or high banks, wherever the arhat passes,
No one does not receive blessings.
They enjoy solitude, which ordinary people cannot do. How delightful to be without expectations, without anything to seek.
Chapter 16: The Chapter on Recitation, from the Dhammapada, with sixteen sections. The chapter on recitation shows that studying many scriptures is not as important as concise clarity.
Although one may recite a thousand words, if the meaning of the phrases is not correct, it is not as good as a single essential point.
Hearing it can extinguish the mind.
Although one may recite a thousand words, if they are not meaningful, what benefit is there?
It is not as good as a single meaning, hearing and practicing can lead to liberation.
Although one may recite many scriptures, if one does not understand, what benefit is there?
Understanding a single phrase of the Dharma, practicing it can lead to the Way.
A single man may defeat a thousand enemies, but it is not as good as conquering oneself.
Conquering oneself is the most virtuous, therefore called a hero. Guarding the mind, disciplining the body, harming oneself to the end.
Although called the honored gods, spirits, demons, and Brahma, none can surpass the person who conquers themselves.
Worshipping a thousand times a month, without ceasing for one's whole life, is not as good as for a moment
Single-mindedly contemplating the Dharma. The merit of a single thought of the Way surpasses that of a lifetime.
Even if one serves fire worship for a hundred years, it is not as good as for a moment
Making offerings to the Three Jewels. The merit of a single offering surpasses that of a hundred years.
Sacrificing to the gods in search of blessings, following after to observe their rewards,
One-fourth is not as good as one-tenth, not as good as paying homage to the wise.
Those who are good at practicing etiquette and always respect the elderly,
The four blessings naturally increase, with complexion, strength, longevity, and peace.
If a person lives a hundred years, far from the right and not upholding precepts,
It is not as good as being born for a day, guarding the precepts, with right intention and meditation;
If a person lives a hundred years, with wrong and deceitfulness, lacking wisdom,
It is not as good as being born for a day, single-mindedly studying right wisdom;
If a person lives for a hundred years, lazy and not diligent,
It is not as good as being born for a day and striving with vigor;
If a person lives for a hundred years without knowing right from wrong,
It is not as good as being born for a day and seeing the subtle and knowing what to avoid;
If a person lives for a hundred years without seeing the path of nectar,
It is not as good as being born for a day and partaking of the taste of nectar;
If a person lives for a hundred years without knowing the meaning of the great way,
It is not as good as being born for a day and studying the essentials of the Buddha's teachings.

Chapter on Evil Conduct, Chapter 17 of the Dharma Verses Sutra, with 22 sections. The chapter on evil conduct is about how evil people will inevitably receive punishment for their actions, while those who do not act will have no problems.
Seeing good but not following it, instead following evil thoughts, seeking blessings in an improper way,
Instead enjoying deviant sexual practices.
Ordinary people commit evil deeds, unable to be aware of themselves, foolishly enjoying themselves, causing later distress and poison.
Sages practice cruelty, sinking and gradually increasing, enjoying desires for people, the retribution of sins is natural;
Virtuous people practice virtue, following and accumulating more, willingly doing it,
the blessings and responses are natural.
Evil people see blessings, their evil is not yet ripe, when their evil ripens, they themselves receive the punishment;
The upright see misfortune, their goodness is not yet ripe, when their goodness ripens, they will definitely receive its blessings.
Hitting others gets hit, practicing resentment gets resentment, scolding others gets scolded,
giving anger gets anger.
People in the world are ignorant, not knowing the right Dharma.
Born with this short life, how can one do evil?
Thinking there is no calamity, the water drops are indeed small, but gradually filling a large vessel,
All sins are filled, accumulated from small beginnings;
Thinking there is no merit, water drops are tiny, but gradually filling a large vessel,
All blessings are filled, accumulated from the slightest.
When a person acts, whether good or evil, each for their own body, it will not end in failure.
Those who like to take, think it is acceptable, those who drown in taking,
People will also drown them.
Evil does not immediately appear, like milking a cow, sins lurk in the shadows, like ashes covering fire.
Jokingly committing evil, acting with the body, crying and receiving retribution, following one's actions, sins arrive.
Committing evil without concealment, like being cut by a soldier, dragged away and only then realizing,
One has already fallen into evil conduct.
Later receiving painful retribution, as previously practiced.
Like poison touching a wound, or a boat entering a whirlpool, evil conduct spreads and proliferates,
harming everyone.
Adding evil and falsely accusing others, even the pure and innocent are defiled,
the fool's calamity rebounds upon himself, like dust blowing against the wind.
Mistakes, offenses, and evil can be regretted and corrected,
this is the illumination of the world, like the sun without clouds or haze.
The reason a person acts is to see for himself,
doing good brings good, doing evil brings evil.
The conscious falls into the womb, the evil enter hell,
practicing good ascends to heaven, being formless attains nirvana.
Not in empty space, not in the ocean, not hiding in the mountains or rocks,
there is no place to escape the evil retribution of past karma.
Sentient beings have suffering and distress, unable to escape old age and death,
Only the benevolent and wise ones do not think of others' faults and evils.

Chapter on Swords and Staffs, Chapter 18 of the Dharma-phrases Sutra, with 14 sections. The chapter on swords and staffs teaches the practice of benevolence and kindness, and prohibits the use of swords and staffs to harm sentient beings.
All fear death, and none do not dread the pain of a staff.
Extend mercy to others as you would to yourself, do not kill, and do not use a staff.
Those who can always bring peace to the masses, and do not inflict harm and pain,
will not encounter harm in this life, and will have lasting peace in the next life.
One should not speak harshly, words should be feared as retribution, evil leads to misfortune,
swords and staffs return to the body.
Speaking with kindness is like striking a bell or chime, if one's body is beyond reproach, transcending the world becomes easy.
Beating the innocent with a staff, falsely accusing the guiltless, the calamity is tenfold, the disaster is swift and unforgivable.
In this life one suffers cruel pain;
Their bodies will be damaged and broken;
They will naturally suffer from illness;
They will lose their minds and become confused;
They will be falsely accused by others;
They may face calamities from the county government;
Their wealth and property will be exhausted;
Their relatives and loved ones will be separated from them;
Their homes and possessions will be burned by disaster fires;
After death, they will enter hell.
These are the ten.ğŸ”½Even if one shaves their head and wears long grass robes,
and bathes while sitting on a rock,
how can they dispel the bonds of delusion?ğŸ”½Not cutting down, killing, or burning,
and not seeking victory, loved by people and the world, wherever one goes there will be no resentment.
Being able to know shame and conscience, this is called progress,ğŸ”½like urging a good horse,
like urging a good horse, one can go far on the path.ğŸ”½If a person has faith, precepts, concentration, and diligence,
and receives the wisdom of the Way, they will extinguish all suffering.
Adorn oneself by cultivating the Dharma, eliminate harm and accept pure practices,
The staff does not harm living beings, this is the way of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Harmless to the world, one will never encounter harm in one's lifetime,
Always compassionate to all, who can become an enemy?

Chapter on Aging and Decay, Chapter 19 of the Fa Jue Jing, with 14 sections. The chapter on aging and decay teaches people to be diligent and not compete with fate. What benefit is there in regretting old age?
What joy?
What laughter?
Life is always burning, deeply hidden in the dark, as if not seeking a lamp.
Seeing the form and appearance, relying on it for peace, much thought leads to illness, how can one know it is not true?
Old age then weakens the appearance, illness has no luster, the skin is loose and the muscles shrink, death is imminent.
When the body dies, the spirit moves away, like a driver abandoning a carriage, the flesh melts and the bones scatter,
How can one rely on the body?
The body is like a city, with bones as the frame and flesh as the plaster. From birth to old age and death, it only conceals anger and arrogance.
When old, the form changes, like an old carriage. The Dharma can remove suffering, so one should diligently study it.
If a person is ignorant, even if old like a bull, only growing fatter,
They will have no blessings or wisdom.
In birth and death, there is no leisure. Coming and going is difficult. If the mind clings to the body, suffering arises without end.
Wisdom sees suffering, therefore one abandons the body. Extinguishing the mind and cutting off craving, love ends and there is no more birth.
Not cultivating pure conduct, nor being wealthy, old like a white egret,
Waiting by an empty pond.
Not observing precepts, nor accumulating wealth, old and weak, with exhausted energy, thinking of the past, what can be done?
Old like autumn leaves, what filth is recorded?
If one's life is quickly taken away, one will regret it.
As life is exhausted day and night, one should be diligent in time.
The truth of the world is impermanent, do not be deluded and fall into darkness.
One should study to ignite the lamp of the mind, train oneself to seek wisdom,
Be free from defilements and do not be stained, hold the torch and observe the path.

Chapter on Cherishing the Body, Chapter 20 of the Dharma Verses Sutra, with 13 sections. The chapter on cherishing the body encourages learning, ultimately benefiting oneself - extinguishing sins and creating blessings.
Those who cherish their bodies should be cautious in guarding what they keep, hoping to understand,
and study the right path without sleep.ğŸ”½For the sake of the body, always strive to learn, benefit others, and not be lazy, then one will be wise.
Learning first corrects oneself, and then corrects others, regulating the body and entering wisdom, one will surely ascend to a higher level.
If one's body cannot benefit oneself, how can one benefit others?
With a disciplined mind and upright body, what wishes are not fulfilled?
What one creates in the past, one will receive in the future. Doing evil to oneself is like using a hard drill to bore a jewel.
If one does not uphold precepts, one will grow like a vine, indulging in desires and increasing evil deeds day by day.
Evil conduct endangers one's body, but fools think it is easy;
Good conduct is the best for maintaining one's body, but fools think it is difficult.
Like the teachings of true people, using the Dharma to maintain the body, fools despise it, seeing it as evil.
Like planting bitter seeds, one will receive evil consequences; planting good seeds, one will receive blessings.
They must each ripen, and one cannot take the place of another;
It is also like planting sweet seeds, benefiting oneself and others, benefiting without wasting.
If you want to know what benefits the body, precepts and learning are the best.
If one has self-worry and wishes to be reborn in the heavens, one should respectfully enjoy hearing the Dharma and remember the Buddha's teachings.
Whatever is used must be pre-planned, do not let it harm what is important,
In this way, the mind is cultivated daily, and affairs are not lost in time.
The one who manages affairs can ultimately achieve benefits,
Truly seeing the body should practice like this, and thus attain what is desired.

Chapter on Worldly Affairs, Chapter 21 of the Dharma Verses Sutra, with 14 sections. The chapter on worldly affairs discusses the world as an illusion and dream, one should abandon vanity and strive to cultivate the path.
Like a cart traveling on a road, abandoning the level and wide path, following a crooked and narrow path, it will break down,
and one will have the worry of a broken axle.
Departing from the Dharma like this, following non-dharma increases, the foolish guard until death, and there are also the afflictions of breaking.
Follow the right path and do not engage in evil deeds. Whether walking, standing, lying down, or at ease, may you be free from troubles throughout all lifetimes.
All things are like bubbles, the mind is like a wild horse, living in the world is like an illusion.
How can one take pleasure in this?
If one can cut this off, like cutting the roots of a tree, day and night like this, one will surely attain concentration.
One offering is like faith, like a joyful person, or from an irritated mind, providing food and drink to the assembly.
This kind of person will not attain concentration day and night. The worldly have no eyes,
and do not see the true path.
Like seeing a little light, one should nurture the wholesome mind, like a goose leading a flock, avoiding the net and soaring high.
A wise person guides the world and delivers the misguided masses.
The world all ends in death, the three realms are not secure. Although the heavens are blissful, when merit is exhausted, one is also lost.
Contemplate that in the world, there is no birth that does not end. If you wish to escape from birth and death, you should practice the true path.
Ignorance covers the world, greed prevents seeing, wrong views turn away from the path,
suffering and foolishness follow from this.
One dharma leads to escape, namely false speech. One cannot avoid the next world, and will experience all evils.
Although one may accumulate many precious treasures, towering up to the heavens,
like this, filling the world, it is not as good as seeing the path.
The unwholesome appears like the wholesome, love appears like non-love,
taking suffering as an appearance of happiness, the deluded man is disgusted by it.
Preface to the Sutra of the Collection of the Dharma, Scroll 1 Preface to the Sutra of the Collection of the Dharma: The verses of Dharmapada are the essential meaning of the sutras;
Dharma means the Dharma, and pada means verses.
There are several versions of the Sutra of the Collection of the Dharma, with 900 verses, or 700 verses, and 500 verses.
GÄthÄ means a concluding verse, like a poem or hymn;
This was spoken by the Buddha upon seeing an event, not all at once, each having its own origin, scattered throughout various sÅ«tras.
The Buddha, with omniscience and a greatly benevolent nature, felt pity for the world and appeared in the world to reveal the meaning of the Way.
He taught people in twelve divisions of the scriptures, summarizing their essentials and compiling them into several sections.

The four Ä€gamas were transmitted by Ä€nanda after the Buddha's passing. The scrolls have no fixed size, all beginning with Thus have I heard, stating where the Buddha was, and fully expounding his teachings.

Later, the five schools of Å›ramaá¹‡as each compiled the four-line and six-line gÄthÄs from various sÅ«tras, arranging them in order to form chapters, drawing from all twelve divisions of the scriptures, with no fixed title, thus called Dharmapada.
Various sÅ«tras are called dharma words, and dharmapada is derived from dharma words.
Recently, the seven hundred verses of the Ge family were transmitted. The meaning of the verses is profound, and the translator has made them quite confused.

Only the Buddha is difficult to encounter, and his texts are difficult to hear. Moreover, all the Buddhas appeared in India. The language of India is different from the sounds of China. It is said that their writing is heavenly writing and their language is heavenly language. The names and objects are different, and it is not easy to transmit the truth.

Only in the past, An Shigao, the Marquis of Lan, and Zhi Chan, the General of the Great Wei, translated from Sanskrit into Chinese, and they truly grasped the essence. This is already difficult to continue.
Later transmitters, although they could not be secretive, still always valued their treasures, roughly grasping the main point.

At the beginning, Vighna came from India and arrived in Wuchang in the third year of Huangwu. His followers received this copy of the five hundred verses and asked his fellow practitioner Zhu Jiangyan to translate it.

Although Zhu Fonian was proficient in the language of India, he was not yet fully conversant with Chinese. The words he transmitted were sometimes in Sanskrit or sometimes in meaning-based pronunciation, simple and genuine.
At first, Zhu Fonian was modest, saying his expressions were not elegant. Zhi Qian said:
The Buddha said:
'Rely on the meaning, not on the adornment; take the Dharma, not the embellishment.
Those who transmit the sutra should make it easy to understand, without losing the meaning, this is good.'
Everyone in the assembly said:
Laozi said:
'Do not believe in beautiful words, believe in words that are true.
' Confucius also said:
'The written word does not exhaust the spoken word, the spoken word does not exhaust the meaning.'
It is clear that the intention of the sages is profound and limitless. Now transmitting the meaning of the Sanskrit, it is truly appropriate to pass through the barrier.

Therefore, from the verses received to the translator's mouth, he followed the original meaning without adding literary embellishment. As for what he did not understand, he left it out and did not transmit it, so there were omissions and many things left out.

Although the words are simple and the meaning profound, the text is concise yet the meaning is extensive, and the events are connected to various sÅ«tras, with chapters having both verses and prose explanations.
In India, beginners who do not study the Dhammapada are considered to have skipped the introduction.

This is the great beginning for beginners and the profound treasury for those who have entered deeply. It can enlighten the confused, discern delusions, and guide people to establish themselves. The merit of studying it is subtle yet what it encompasses is vast. It can truly be called wonderful and essential.
In the past, when transmitting this, there were some points that were not understood. When the master was about to leave, he consulted with the master again.

Receiving these verses, he obtained thirteen chapters, and comparing them with the ancient texts, there were some additions and corrections. The chapter titles were combined into a total of thirty-nine chapters, with a total of seven hundred and fifty-two verses. It is hoped that there will be some benefit, and it can be widely inquired about.
